title: Kain panjang
content:

  physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features stylised phoenixes flying amidst cloud motifs
 against a plain dark indigo blue background. The motifs are further embellished with intricate secondary filler patterns. The right and left ends of the batik kain panjang is bordered by a repeated scrolling pattern. There is a signature on the bottom-left of the batik kain panjang.

  subject_terms_1: phoenixes Peranakan foliage (motif)

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Batik

  subject_terms_3: Peranakan costumes Batik

  sgcool_label_text: Phonexies amidst clouds (or the megamendung motif) divide the kain panjang into three vertical sections.  Although the entire design is set against a plain indigo blue background
 the phoenixes’ plumage and tail feathers are rendered sensitively
 emphasising their graceful flight.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art” Unique Pekalongan Ind”.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features stylised phoenixes flying amidst cloud motifs, against a plain dark indigo blue background. The motifs are further embellished with intricate secondary filler patterns. The right and left ends of the batik kain panjang is bordered by a repeated scrolling pattern. There is a signature on the bottom-left of the batik kain panjang.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Batik
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Phonexies amidst clouds (or the megamendung motif) divide the kain panjang into three vertical sections.  Although the entire design is set against a plain indigo blue background, the phoenixes’ plumage and tail feathers are rendered sensitively, emphasising their graceful flight.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art” Unique Pekalongan Ind”.
